Many many years ago while a lowly medical student, I read The Island of the Colour-blind and Cycad Island and came away a little underwhelmed. A grand desire to avoid any form of medical writing since has kept me away from the rest of his catalogue but with his recent death I decided to pick up one of his more famous titles.I struggled. I think part of the issue is the intervening 30 years since publication. He's firmly routed in a somewhat outmoded form of neurology and it shows (plus he seems to love Freud). Ideas and knowledge have moved on and it makes it hard to appreciate read with modern understanding. He's also clearly got some idols and almost every anecdote is linked to them in some way without him really explaining their significance (aside from a brief mention in the bibliography). His thoughts and interpretations comprise an odd mix of neurology, psychiatry and quasi-mysticism with a little sociology, philosophy and bullshitting thrown into the mix. There's definitely some ego at play here. I generally didn't accept his interpretations or like the style as a result and agree that his flowery repetitive prose can get a little muddling at times.I had no issue with the terminology though I'm not sure the lay public would necessarily find it that easy to pick up without a glossary or some Wikipedia work. I'm not entirely sure which audience he's writing for.If you throw in some outdated and insulting terminology, some terribly written reconstructed dialogue and a disjointed structure, it just didn't work for me.He was clearly an intelligent guy who deeply cared about his patients and put a huge amount of thought into the inner workings of the mind. He just isn't for me.

The first time I heard of Man who Mistook His Wife for a Hat, I was amused that anyone would do that--see his wife and think 'hat'? How silly! I figured when I read the book, I'd find this was a clever play on words. It didn't take long, though--less than a chapter--to find out that this was the world of one man and his psychosis. His brain couldn't collect the pieces picked up by his eyes and put them together sufficiently to determine what was his wife and what was the thing he'd put on his head to keep it dry.Sacks tells this story, and many other odd illnesses that our fellow humans suffer, with empathy and knowledge but no pity. I like that. He approaches these individuals with an interest in helping them recover a reality they've lost, not with any attitude that they are somehow lessor individuals because their bodies have stopped functioning like those around them. As a writer, I want to 1) include these fascinating oddities into my characters, and 2) share his sense of wonder about what is outside the norm with my readers.I came away from my time spent with Oliver Sacks and his patients wondering what I've missed when watching others, what goes on in their brains that I can't see and maybe haven't taken the time to understand. Is the human race more different than the same? Now, one book richer in my intellect, I'm quite sure that the slight difference in DNA between us and chimps and other life forms doesn't nearly tell the real story of life and its many forms.

So this is going to read as non-sequitur but stay with me here: I read World War Z earlier this year and the prologue is about the main character turning in a report to the CDC. The CDC is only concerned with hard numbers and facts, but our narrator is concerned with the "human aspect". The CDC wants him to eliminate the humanity from his report and give only hard science, while he feels the "human aspect" is what will heal the world after this zombie apocalypse. That is how I feel about Oliver Sacks' The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat and Other Clinical Tales. We all know someone suffering from some type of mental abnormality. I, myself suffer from anxiety and have suffered from chronic panic attacks in my youth. However, in an attempt to make Psychology a "hard science" instead of a "soft science" which in the academic world is consistently looked down upon we tend to lose the humanity. Sacks' case studies are a humbling look at imperfection and how despite those imperfections, we are all still human. I will say that Sacks does stick to fairly dense, clinical and dry language throughout the book. However, I find my self consistently in awe that despite this, the humanity is the message that shines through. This is well worth anyone's time to read that has interest in anything psychology related.

An interesting glimpse at some neurological case studies presented by the humanist Dr. Sachs.Sachs does a great job at introducing the reader to people with neurological ailments in these case studies, paying attention to the individuals and not just their disabilities. That being said I found myself wanting a bit more depth to the cases, more back story, more biography, it seemed so brief in many of the cases, but I do understand that was by design, introducing people to multiple interesting neurological occurrences in a succinct manner before moving on to the next. Sachs is famous for insisting in presenting cases in a narrative format and examining patients in a more organic way, assessing them scientifically, but also treating them as individuals and then making the cases accessible to laymen as well as his peers. You do find yourself wrangling with some neurological jargon, nothing that one shouldn't be able to break down or infer the meaning though. Sachs's love for a long sentence can be a bit cumbersome at times, utilizing the comma to it's breaking point before presenting the reader with a colon, many more commas, a statement that needs the aid of parentheses and maybe a dash or two just for funsies.

This book was amazing. One of the case studies is one of those that all introductory psychology literature mentions about agnosia. The book feels very dated, with talk of “dullards”, “simpletons” and “savages”. (At least “savages” is always in quotation marks!). The science lies all in the past - it is incredible how close the 1980s, when this book was published, is to today, and yet, the science has advanced by leaps and bounds.Especially fascinating was the horrible case of the woman who lost proprioception.Interesting was the part about Tourette’s and how he described it as the first case where patients actively contributed to cures and solutions for their condition. The change from the autocratic doctor and today’s empowered patient (at least in theory) is palpable.His love for the patients that are different is clear, and how he feels that they are being needlessly neglected and should be valued for what they can contribute to society.... It is beautiful. I’m wondering what today’s autism activists think of the part in the book where he wrote about it.A definitive recommend for anyone interested in this early history of modern psychology.

I picked up this book because my son read it and related some fascinating stories from it. The depictions of the various problems of Dr.Sacks's clients are amazing. Of course, that's just my opinion. There were points where I found myself drifting, especially when the author starts to wax philosophical. I guess I was just more interested in the client's stories and about what happened to them, rather than any thoughts on whether or not they had souls.

There are but a few minor things that I would like to have seen tweaked.One, the inclusion of a glossary as I lost track of the meaning of some of the technical terms over the course of the read.Two, an updated edition with addenda explaining how these scenarios would be considered by modern medical science. This is a book about a doctor who treats patients with mental issues; I loved the reflections on what these patients revealed about being human. He talks about a patient suffering from autism, and says:-She had done appallingly in the testing— which, in a sense, was designed, like all neurological and psychological testing, not merely to uncover, to bring out deficits, but to decompose her into functions and deficits. She had come apart, horribly, in formal testing, but now she was mysteriously 'together' and composed. Why was she so decomposed before, how could she be so re-composed now? I had the strongest feeling of two wholly different modes of thought, or of organization, or of being. The first schematic— pattern-seeing, problem-solving— this is what had been tested, and where she had been found so defective, so disastrously wanting. But the tests had given no inkling of anything but the deficits, of anything, so to speak, beyond her deficits. They had given me no hint of her positive powers, her ability to perceive the real world— the world of nature, and perhaps of the imagination— as a coherent, intelligible, poetic whole: her ability to see this, think this, and (when she could) live this; they had given me no intimation of her inner world, which clearly was composed and coherent, and approached as something other than a set of problems or tasks.It's a very apt characterisation of people - and I enjoyed the focus on looking at people's strengths, or abilities, rather than their defects. The chapters are mostly short, and can be read alone, so it's an easily readable book.

I think this is a very good book and although is a specialized one, the cases presented there are in a such way that everybody can understand and learn.

IntroductionI have been looking forward to read The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat‘ for more than a year. Somehow, it had never made it to my “Currently Reading” list. The death of its author, Dr. Oliver Sacks, a neurologist, prompted me to actually start reading it.According to the author, there has been a serious dearth of good medical case writing in the 20th century. He refers back to the 19th century which was the heyday of such writing.What sort of writing are we talking about? The author wants to add back emotions and identities, instead of making cases impersonal. People who have read Sherlock Holmes or other literature (fiction/non-fiction) from the 19th century will be able to recognise such writing – for e.g. – referring to a patient as Johnny G or Dr P.This book deals with some neurological cases with emphasis on right brain defects and deficiencies. There are 24 different topics that the book covers. These include some made popular by movies like Kursakoff’s syndrome in Memento or Autistic Savants in House of Cards. These topics have fanciful names like “The Lost Mariner” and “The Disembodied Lady” etc.RecommendationI have to confess – much as I wanted to like this book, I found it a chore to read. In the end, I stopped midway due to the sheer drudgery involved in going through the indecipherable prose as well as the incomprehensible medical jargon. Either of the two would have been fine on its own; but their combination makes for dull reading.The author cannot seem to make up his mind – is this a book that talks about these cases from an entertainment perspective or is this book a medical text. If the former, then it fails at holding the reader’s imagination and does the cardinal mistake of interjecting a lot of serious medical terms. If the latter, then the book fails at presenting the facts, the diagnosis and the conclusion.

I'd picked this book up thinking it would be a light, undemanding read - a collection of medical oddities and bizarre tales. Some of the tales do fall into this category: The Disembodied Lady (about a woman who suffers a loss of proprioception), Hands (about a woman who doesn't regard her hands as being part of herself) and Phantoms (about phantom limbs). But other tales were more a reflection on the human condition. In the title tale, Sacks muses over severe visual agnosia and its destruction of Mr P's sense of the concrete, how he perceives and interprets the world. In The Lost Mariner, Sacks discusses whether a patient with severe amnesia - where the patient can no longer recall any event beyond 5 minutes - can really be described as living. For what is a life with no memories of experiences and relationships?Some of the tales discussed how a patient's neurological condition was seen (by the patient) as adding to, rather than detracting from, his sense of self and life. Witty Ticcy Ray - about a Tourette sufferer - in many ways reminded me of Kay Redfield Jamison's An Unquiet Mind on her experience with bipolar disorder. How there were many lows, but there were exquisite moments on the upswing, when the creativity, energy and sense of clarity she had was addictive and exhilerating. The section on "The World of the Simple" was probably the most intriguing for me, with its tales of Rebecca (a so-called simpleton who had an appreciation of the concrete and narrative in poetry and music), the Autist Artist, the Twins and A Walking Grove (on a patient with retardation but an amazing musical memory)

My love for Oliver Sacks had been based solely on what I'd heard him talk about, and his inquisitive, twinkle-eyed persona, in many a media interview over the years. That, and what little memory I have of the Robin Williams film. I'd never actually read him. I adore him even more, now. This, his fourth and one of his most well-known books, was almost completely a delight. My only small quibble was with the introduction and some of the postscripts where his prose lapsed into medical jargon and lost me. Otherwise, Sacks writes about his patients with lush perception and compassion. The highest compliment I can pay is that I often forgot I was reading non-fiction: he brings his patients alive on the page with a novelist's flair.Whether it's the man who mistook his wife for a hat (this chapter is doubly poignant with the knowledge that Sacks himself was much later diagnosed with face blindness), the man with Tourette's, the nearly 90-year-old lady with the suddenly explosive libido, the mentally retarded twins who couldn't say what two plus two equaled but could tell you within a split second exactly how many marbles fell onto the floor after a jar full of them tipped over, Sacks imbues his patients with humanity and dignity. What's more, in many cases, he agrees with them when they say they don't wish for a complete cure because their neurological problems actually enrich their lives. Sometimes, Sacks would halve the meds to enable his patients to find the right balance.That becomes a lovely metaphor for living any kind of life with zany dignity.

I read these case histories over the course of several weeks, interspersing with my other reading. I find this works best for me for this type of book as well as for short stories. I suppose it's true with anything of this sort that some of the chapters were fascinating while others were downright dull. I did not especially care for the title story, but perhaps that's just because it was first and I had not yet settled into the presentations. This collection was first published in 1985, but the essays were first published earlier - some of them as much as 20 years earlier. Each has a postscript. Sometimes the postscript is a follow-up of the patient, others discuss essays by other authors about similar subjects.Sometime in the past couple of years, I was reminded that our body replaces hundreds of thousands of cells daily. Sometimes it makes mistakes. Reading this collection, I learned about some of the ways it can make mistakes. I paused to consider how well the body does this cell replacing and that it doesn't go wrong more often. At least I 
think
 it hasn't gotten it wrong in my case. In spite of its being dated and I'm sure much research would bring some of Sacks' conclusions current, this was well worth the time. If I had not been reading for a challenge, however, I might have been willing to skim or skip some of the chapters. Because of that, I cannot give this more than 3 stars.

Twenty-four case studies, grouped under four rubrics: Losses (amnesia, total loss of proprioception, etc); Excesses (Tourette’s, a Korsakov’s patient in a state of constant, frantic confabulation as a defense against amnesia, etc); Transports (cases of involuntary reminiscence and heightened senses); and The World of the Simple (autistic and retarded patients, mostly with eidetic powers).Though it’s much more clinical in style than An Anthropologist on Mars: Seven Paradoxical Tales, this is still an interesting collection. Sacks makes a good case that a mind-set which is entirely abstract (the most fascinating titular patient) is even more alien than one which grasps only concretes, like the autistic. He also critiques the “working vs. deficient” model of neurology, depicting phenomena and mental breakthroughs that can only come into being outside of the laboratory and traditional testing. Aside from his arguments, as a collection of anecdotes, this book is enthralling and terrifying, an amazing look into just a few of the wondrous, bizarre ways mind can malfunction.

I will begin with a quote: “If a man has lost a leg or an eye, he knows he has lost a leg or an eye; but if he has lost a self—himself—he cannot know it, because he is no longer there to know it.” - and it was hard to choose only one. This book was a delight, a painful and heavy delight. It left me naked in front of my own self and made me question myself and the way I see other people (as if I wan't doing that already). My rotation on stroke helped me understand it even more, helped me immerse myself even more in its stories. I wish I read it long ago, can't believe I spent 7 years in medicine without reading it. A reflection of the depths that my mind reaches every day, it spoke to me with every phrase, more than every other book related to medicine/the life of a doctor has done so far. I have found a new favourite book.

This is amongst the best known of Sacks' works. The improbability of the title representing a real situation is perhaps part of the reason for this, but Sacks gives a glimpse into the worlds of people whose brains and nervous systems don't function normally, leading them to behave in unusual ways. He was one of the first scientists to write for a popular audience about what happens when parts of brains misbehave; when the circuitry of the nervous system has a short in it somewhere or just isn't wired the way most people are wired. His earlier books, like this, may seem simple to some recent reviewers coming across them for the first time, but at the time he wrote them they were revelatory. Still worth reading if you haven't already and you are interested in how humans work.

I love how Sacks, through his small clinical vignettes, exposes the complex, narrative powers of the brain. Written with a clinician's eye, but a poet's heart, I also love how he is able to show how these patients with all sorts of neurological deficits, disabilities, and divergences are able to adapt and even thrive despite their neurological damage. For the most part, they are able to find "a new health, a new freedom" through music, inner narratives, etc. They are able to achieve a "Great Health," a peace and a paradoxical wellness THROUGH their illness.

I found this hard going. I loved it. I've always been interested in brain science nonfiction stuff, so this was worth the re-read. I really loved the conversational tone Sacks uses.The stories should be accessible to everyone moderately interested in the topic of the chapter at hand, though since I read this decades after it was written, I already knew some of what Sacks was getting at before the 'big reveals'. Sacks, there is no denying that, is a brilliant scientist. He not only takes upon the tradition of describing individuals in all their personal stories to better serve clinical classifications (an approach which was common in the 19th century, especially in psychiatry, but had sadly gotten lost over time) but, also, manages here to display a wide range of cases all illustrating neurodiversity, more than thirty years before the word 'neurodiversity' itself was even coined! Is it visionary? Kind of.Kind of because, if with some cases he keep his promise of explaining the reasons why behind a particular condition or diagnosis (e.g. what is agnosia, and why it can lead to a man mistaking his wife for a hat!) most cases here are just pictures of people with weird beliefs and/ or behaviours without much of explaining. But other tales were more a reflection on the human condition. In the title tale, Sacks muses over severe visual agnosia and its destruction of Mr P's sense of the concrete, how he perceives and interprets the world. In The Lost Mariner, Sacks discusses whether a patient with severe amnesia - where the patient can no longer recall any event beyond 5 minutes - can really be described as living. For what is a life with no memories of experiences and relationships?Some of the tales discussed how a patient's neurological condition was seen (by the patient) as adding to, rather than detracting from, his sense of self and life. Witty Ticcy Ray - about a Tourette sufferer - in many ways reminded me of Kay Redfield Jamison's An Unquiet Mind on her experience with bipolar disorder. How there were many lows, but there were exquisite moments on the upswing, when the creativity, energy and sense of clarity she had was addictive and exhilerating. The section on "The World of the Simple" was probably the most intriguing for me, with its tales of Rebecca (a so-called simpleton who had an appreciation of the concrete and narrative in poetry and music), the Autist Artist, the Twins and A Walking Grove (on a patient with retardation but an amazing musical memory)

My love for Oliver Sacks had been based solely on what I'd heard him talk about, and his inquisitive, twinkle-eyed persona, in many a media interview over the years. That, and what little memory I have of the Robin Williams film. I'd never actually read him. I adore him even more, now. This, his fourth and one of his most well-known books, was almost completely a delight. My only small quibble was with the introduction and some of the postscripts where his prose lapsed into medical jargon and lost me. Otherwise, Sacks writes about his patients with lush perception and compassion. The highest compliment I can pay is that I often forgot I was reading non-fiction: he brings his patients alive on the page with a novelist's flair.Whether it's the man who mistook his wife for a hat (this chapter is doubly poignant with the knowledge that Sacks himself was much later diagnosed with face blindness), the man with Tourette's, the nearly 90-year-old lady with the suddenly explosive libido, the mentally retarded twins who couldn't say what two plus two equaled but could tell you within a split second exactly how many marbles fell onto the floor after a jar full of them tipped over, Sacks imbues his patients with humanity and dignity. What's more, in many cases, he agrees with them when they say they don't wish for a complete cure because their neurological problems actually enrich their lives. Sometimes, Sacks would halve the meds to enable his patients to find the right balance.That becomes a lovely metaphor for living any kind of life with zany dignity.

Twenty-four case studies, grouped under four rubrics: Losses (amnesia, total loss of proprioception, etc); Excesses (Tourette’s, a Korsakov’s patient in a state of constant, frantic confabulation as a defense against amnesia, etc); Transports (cases of involuntary reminiscence and heightened senses); and The World of the Simple (autistic and retarded patients, mostly with eidetic powers).Though it’s much more clinical in style than An Anthropologist on Mars: Seven Paradoxical Tales, this is still an interesting collection. Sacks makes a good case that a mind-set which is entirely abstract (the most fascinating titular patient) is even more alien than one which grasps only concretes, like the autistic. He also critiques the “working vs. deficient” model of neurology, depicting phenomena and mental breakthroughs that can only come into being outside of the laboratory and traditional testing. Aside from his arguments, as a collection of anecdotes, this book is enthralling and terrifying, an amazing look into just a few of the wondrous, bizarre ways mind can malfunction.

I have found a new favourite book.

After having read An Anthropologist on Mars: Seven Paradoxical Tales by the same author, I decided to pick this up. Will it be as good? Well, it's supposed to follow the same recipe: bring in a patient suffering from a weird case or condition, dissect it clinically so as to illustrate how the human brain works, and, leave it to the reader to ponder upon how such cases, as striking and bizarre as they can be moving and touching, can lead to question what constitutes a 'self', or even being human. Sacks, there is no denying that, is a brilliant scientist. He not only takes upon the tradition of describing individuals in all their personal stories to better serve clinical classifications (an approach which was common in the 19th century, especially in psychiatry, but had sadly gotten lost over time) but, also, manages here to display a wide range of cases all illustrating neurodiversity, more than thirty years before the word 'neurodiversity' itself was even coined! Is it visionary? Kind of.Kind of because, if with some cases he keep his promise of explaining the reasons why behind a particular condition or diagnosis (e.g. what is agnosia, and why it can lead to a man mistaking his wife for a hat!) most cases here are just pictures of people with weird beliefs and/ or behaviours without much of explaining. Here's a great catalogue of strange although touching people, but not very instructive when it comes to actually learning something about neuropsychology. Also, as much as I acknowledge his huge success and bestseller status, let's bear in mind that this was first published in 1985. It surely might have been ground-breaking back then, but what about now? For example, among his bizarre patients portrayed here feature a few autistic people, and, the way he describes them smacks of how it was back in the 70s and 80s -they are referred to as 'retarded', 'morons', 'simpleton', and not much is expected of them, to the point of Sacks himself being baffled by some of their actual abilities! His view was the view of most of the medical community (let alone society at large) back then, and, to his credit, we see him challenging his own misconceptions and prejudices - a complete shift which will lead him to a whole new perception in one of his later book, An Anthropologist on Mars: Seven Paradoxical Tales (which will feature Temple Grandin and Stephen Wiltshire...). Interestingly enough, a whole chapter also about autism ('The Twins', featuring encounters which had inspired scenes in the movie 'Rain Man'...) was questioned too in Embracing the Wide Sky: A Tour Across the Horizons of the Mind, a book by Daniel Tammet, himself one of these striking 'autist-savant'...To conclude, then, here's more a catalogue of a wide variety of people whose brains are wired differently than the 'norm' than proper lessons on the functioning of the human mind. It's not a bad thing -it's a deeply human and touching display. After having read An Anthropologist on Mars: Seven Paradoxical Tales by the same author, I decided to pick this up. Will it be as good? Well, it's supposed to follow the same recipe: bring in a patient suffering from a weird case or condition, dissect it clinically so as to illustrate how the human brain works, and, leave it to the reader to ponder upon how such cases, as striking and bizarre as they can be moving and touching, can lead to question what constitutes a 'self', or even being human. Sacks, there is no denying that, is a brilliant scientist. He not only takes upon the tradition of describing individuals in all their personal stories to better serve clinical classifications (an approach which was common in the 19th century, especially in psychiatry, but had sadly gotten lost over time) but, also, manages here to display a wide range of cases all illustrating neurodiversity, more than thirty years before the word 'neurodiversity' itself was even coined! Is it visionary? Kind of.Kind of because, if with some cases he keep his promise of explaining the reasons why behind a particular condition or diagnosis (e.g. what is agnosia, and why it can lead to a man mistaking his wife for a hat!) most cases here are just pictures of people with weird beliefs and/ or behaviours without much of explaining. Here's a great catalogue of strange although touching people, but not very instructive when it comes to actually learning something about neuropsychology. Also, as much as I acknowledge his huge success and bestseller status, let's bear in mind that this was first published in 1985. It surely might have been ground-breaking back then, but what about now? For example, among his bizarre patients portrayed here feature a few autistic people, and, the way he describes them smacks of how it was back in the 70s and 80s -they are referred to as 'retarded', 'morons', 'simpleton', and not much is expected of them, to the point of Sacks himself being baffled by some of their actual abilities! Mind you, I am not denigrating the author. His view was the view of most of the medical community (let alone society at large) back then, and, to his credit, we see him challenging his own misconceptions and prejudices - a complete shift which will lead him to a whole new perception in one of his later book, An Anthropologist on Mars: Seven Paradoxical Tales (which will feature Temple Grandin and Stephen Wiltshire...). But, then, if he can be that unsure about autism alone, what about the rest? Interestingly enough, a whole chapter also about autism ('The Twins', featuring encounters which had inspired scenes in the movie 'Rain Man'...) was questioned too in Embracing the Wide Sky: A Tour Across the Horizons of the Mind, a book by Daniel Tammet, himself one of these striking 'autist-savant'...To conclude, then, here's more a catalogue of a wide variety of people whose brains are wired differently than the 'norm' than proper lessons on the functioning of the human mind. It's not a bad thing -it's a deeply human and touching display. Speculations which, at times, can be off the mark! It's interesting. It's engrossing. Yet, despite its jargon (both scientific and philosophical) it wasn't that instructive in terms of neuropsychology. Personally, I enjoyed it but didn't get much.

IntroductionI have been looking forward to read The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat‘ for more than a year. Somehow, it had never made it to my “Currently Reading” list. The death of its author, Dr. Oliver Sacks, a neurologist, prompted me to actually start reading it.According to the author, there has been a serious dearth of good medical case writing in the 20th century. He refers back to the 19th century which was the heyday of such writing.What sort of writing are we talking about? The author wants to add back emotions and identities, instead of making cases impersonal. People who have read Sherlock Holmes or other literature (fiction/non-fiction) from the 19th century will be able to recognise such writing – for e.g. – referring to a patient as Johnny G or Dr P.This book deals with some neurological cases with emphasis on right brain defects and deficiencies. There are 24 different topics that the book covers. These include some made popular by movies like Kursakoff’s syndrome in Memento or Autistic Savants in House of Cards. These topics have fanciful names like “The Lost Mariner” and “The Disembodied Lady” etc.RecommendationI have to confess – much as I wanted to like this book, I found it a chore to read. In the end, I stopped midway due to the sheer drudgery involved in going through the indecipherable prose as well as the incomprehensible medical jargon. Either of the two would have been fine on its own; but their combination makes for dull reading.The author cannot seem to make up his mind – is this a book that talks about these cases from an entertainment perspective or is this book a medical text. If the former, then it fails at holding the reader’s imagination and does the cardinal mistake of interjecting a lot of serious medical terms. If the latter, then the book fails at presenting the facts, the diagnosis and the conclusion.

Some of the tales do fall into this category: The Disembodied Lady (about a woman who suffers a loss of proprioception), Hands (about a woman who doesn't regard her hands as being part of herself) and Phantoms (about phantom limbs). But other tales were more a reflection on the human condition. In the title tale, Sacks muses over severe visual agnosia and its destruction of Mr P's sense of the concrete, how he perceives and interprets the world. In The Lost Mariner, Sacks discusses whether a patient with severe amnesia - where the patient can no longer recall any event beyond 5 minutes - can really be described as living. For what is a life with no memories of experiences and relationships?Some of the tales discussed how a patient's neurological condition was seen (by the patient) as adding to, rather than detracting from, his sense of self and life. Witty Ticcy Ray - about a Tourette sufferer - in many ways reminded me of Kay Redfield Jamison's An Unquiet Mind on her experience with bipolar disorder. How there were many lows, but there were exquisite moments on the upswing, when the creativity, energy and sense of clarity she had was addictive and exhilerating. The section on "The World of the Simple" was probably the most intriguing for me, with its tales of Rebecca (a so-called simpleton who had an appreciation of the concrete and narrative in poetry and music), the Autist Artist, the Twins and A Walking Grove (on a patient with retardation but an amazing musical memory)

My love for Oliver Sacks had been based solely on what I'd heard him talk about, and his inquisitive, twinkle-eyed persona, in many a media interview over the years. This, his fourth and one of his most well-known books, was almost completely a delight. My only small quibble was with the introduction and some of the postscripts where his prose lapsed into medical jargon and lost me. Otherwise, Sacks writes about his patients with lush perception and compassion. The highest compliment I can pay is that I often forgot I was reading non-fiction: he brings his patients alive on the page with a novelist's flair.Whether it's the man who mistook his wife for a hat (this chapter is doubly poignant with the knowledge that Sacks himself was much later diagnosed with face blindness), the man with Tourette's, the nearly 90-year-old lady with the suddenly explosive libido, the mentally retarded twins who couldn't say what two plus two equaled but could tell you within a split second exactly how many marbles fell onto the floor after a jar full of them tipped over, Sacks imbues his patients with humanity and dignity. What's more, in many cases, he agrees with them when they say they don't wish for a complete cure because their neurological problems actually enrich their lives. Sometimes, Sacks would halve the meds to enable his patients to find the right balance.That becomes a lovely metaphor for living any kind of life with zany dignity.
